results.title: Broken China: the earthquake that never happened
results.creator_credit: Liu Chun, Qi Kejun, Xue Song, Chen Meng, Lin Xiezhong, Wei Bin, Yu Bo, Yuan Zhengming, Zhao Shujing, ABC-TV (Australia), CCTV and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Dragon stirs”.
Part one of a four part series about China. On 28 July 1976 a natural disaster - the worst ever recorded in China - killed over a quarter million people in the industrial city of Tang Shang, just 100km east of Beijing. An earthquake of massive proportions ripped the city apart destroying 96% of its buildings and burying alive over 600,000 people, all within 53 seconds. Fearing political unrest with the imminent death of Chairman Mao, the Chinese Government kept the extent of the disaster a State secret rejecting international offers of help preferring instead to send in thousands of their own soldiers from the People’s Liberation Army. This documentary records the amazing effort by the soldiers and the people of Tang Shang to rebuild their city in the aftermath of the earthquake. Through personal interviews by survivors and their stories of heroic acts, miracles, and tragedies, the film provides an insight into the spirit, unity and courage of these people who 20 years on still carry the memories and emotional scars. It is a heart-warming story of humans co-operating together as one in the most adverse of circumstances. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by Peter George and Diana McLean. In Mandarin with English subtitles and commentary in English.
results.title_for_label: Broken China: the earthquake that never happened
results.creator_credit_for_label: Liu Chun, Qi Kejun, Xue Song, Chen Meng, Lin Xiezhong, Wei Bin, Yu Bo, Yuan Zhengming, Zhao Shujing, ABC-TV (Australia), CCTV and Southern Star Entertainment

results.title: Encounters with Islam [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roger Bayley and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
This program discusses the aftermath of September 11 and its impact on Australian Muslims who represent just over 1% of the Australian population. Whilst focusing on some of the negative aspects including vilification, violence and antagonism towards women by non-Muslims, vandal attacks on mosques and a media which seemed to be more intent on dividing the community rather than uniting it, “Encounters with Islam” also seeks to reveal a more positive view. Through interviews with various leaders of the Islamic community, academics, young people and non-Muslims, it is apparent that a re-evaluation is taking place amongst the Muslims and a recognition that their world of Islam needs to be demystified and the Australian population informed. The link of crime and acts of terrorism with Muslims stems from not only the tragedy of September 11, but also preceding incidents in Sydney of gang rapes and drug related crimes allegedly by men of Muslim backgrounds. Misunderstanding and prejudice are trying to be counteracted through dialogue and discussion between the different faiths, support, understanding and a “fair go” by the non-Muslim Australian community and a better educated and more sensitive media. Presented by Geraldine Doogue.

results.title: Secular soul. Part 3. Atheists [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. The final episode looks at four prominent Australian atheists, how they reached their decision to become an atheist and how they live their lives in the absence of religion. Interviewees include: Peter Singer, the child of Jewish refugees and a philosopher and ethicist renowned for his controversial view on euthanasia and animal rights; geology professor Ian Plimer who grew up in Sydney in the 1940s and 50s and took a Christian fundamentalist to court on the grounds that they were peddling misleading information; Diana Warnock, ex West Australian Labor politician and now a community activist; and Dick Gross, former mayor of St Kilda and founder of the Jewish Saturday school, a secular, humanist alternative which involves culture and ethnicity minus the religion. The four speak of the importance of ritual, the possibility of ethics derived from reason as opposed to religion, life after death, and whether religion is increased or decreased in the face of adversity. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

results.title: Secular soul. Part 2. Ceremonies [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. Episode two examines the civil celebrant movement and the increase in rituals involving civil celebrants as opposed to traditional religious leaders. Doogue speaks to civil celebrant Dally Messenger, one of Australia’s longest practising civil celebrants, Diane Storey who specializes in funerals, John Hill, an ex Roman Catholic priest who missed the rituals of the church and became a civil celebrant, Gael Brigden, a celebrant on a television program, and Paul Charvet-Jackson who specialises in same sex commitment ceremonies. The celebrants share their thoughts on what inspires them, how they devise the rituals, the preparation that takes place, and the future of their profession. Features footage of weddings, a naming day and interviews with people who have enlisted the services of the celebrants. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

results.title: Secular soul. Part 1. Spiritual market place [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. Episode one examines the decline in attendance at traditional churches and the incidence of “spiritual shopping” whereby people are creating their own personal style of religion. In looking at the decline in church attendance since the 1960s and the melding of the experiential and the emotional, Doogue speaks to university lecturers Carole Cusack and David Tacey, Uniting Church Minister and director of the Christian Research Association Philip Hughes, and Anglican priest and sociologist Gary Bouma. The program also looks at the growth in Pentecostal churches, spending time at the Mount Annan Christian Life Centre, speaking to Andrew and Adrian Gray about their work. Youths also describe their experiences during an empowering conference. Features vox pops at Sydney nightclub and Acland Street, St Kilda. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

results.title: Chris Patten's east and west
results.creator_credit: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description: Former Governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten provides a politico-economic tour of some countries affected by the Asian economic crisis, speaking with many of the leading economists and politicians involved. He assesses the repercussions of changing attitudes towards Asia, shows how the collapse of the economies of South East Asia have effected ordinary people, and discusses Asian culture and values that have build up over time.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: The Pacific century
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
Final part of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten continues his discussion on the Asian economic miracle questioning the popular belief that the new millenium will belong to the Pacific Rim. He briefly talks about Thailand, from the days of its feudal society to its now modern industrial state which is facing an economic crisis following a crash in the “building boom” of the 1990s. More in depth coverage however, is given to Singapore and Japan - historical, economical and political - pointing out the differences in culture and traditions of both nations and the reasons behind their successes and failures in the world of economics. He points out Singapore’s reliance on its efficient, well educated and willing workforce who forego their individual rights and freedoms for the common good of the State and Japan’s tradition of loyalty to the company and a “job for life” being put under pressure as the younger generation demand freedom and choice in their careers and workplace culture. The program contains several interviews with various leaders and company personnel including the former Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kwan Yew, along with Chris Patten’s personal commentary and opinions. The series is well presented, informative and interesting from a socio-economic point of view - Chris Patten provides the human touch. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Spencer, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
Final part of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten continues his discussion on the Asian economic miracle questioning the popular belief that the new millenium will belong to the Pacific Rim. He briefly talks about Thailand, from the days of its feudal society to its now modern industrial state which is facing an economic crisis following a crash in the “building boom” of the 1990s. More in depth coverage however, is given to Singapore and Japan - historical, economical and political - pointing out the differences in culture and traditions of both nations and the reasons behind their successes and failures in the world of economics. He points out Singapore’s reliance on its efficient, well educated and willing workforce who forego their individual rights and freedoms for the common good of the State and Japan’s tradition of loyalty to the company and a “job for life” being put under pressure as the younger generation demand freedom and choice in their careers and workplace culture. The program contains several interviews with various leaders and company personnel including the former Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kwan Yew, along with Chris Patten’s personal commentary and opinions. The series is well presented, informative and interesting from a socio-economic point of view - Chris Patten provides the human touch. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.

results.title: Tiger talk
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Dent, Kim Jungeun, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
Second of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode the focus is on the economic crisis which spread across Asia during the late 1990s and the reasons behind the death of the so-called “Asian tigers”. Chris Patten points out once again the often crucial missing link with economical reform is political reform. Both Indonesia and South Korea, “Asian tigers” for several decades were ruled by authoritarian Presidents and in Indonesia’s case, the dictator President Suharto and his corrupt family. By presenting a detailed historical background on South Korea and a briefer outlook on Indonesia, Patten attempts to provide an insight and understanding on Asian economics, the relationship between government and private industry, between free trade and the industrial revolution in Asia, political oppression and student uprisings, company debts and the International Monetary Fund and finally the streamlining of the labor market through redundancies and restructure. Included in the program are interviews with B.J. Habibie (President, Republic of Indonesia 1998), Milton Kim (Chairman, Ssangyong Investment & Securities), and Kim Dae Jung (South Korean Opposition Leader 1961-1997). Contains b&w archival footage and stills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jonathan Dent, Kim Jungeun, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: Barbarian diplomacy
results.creator_credit: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
First of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten focuses on China - socially, economically and politically - from its past history to the China of the 90s. He more specifically deals with human rights and economic reform emphasising his strong belief that it is important “to keep trade and human rights separate” and that “economical reform requires political reform”. The program covers President Nixon’s visit and his meeting with Mao Tse-tung in 1972; the US/China alliance and lifting of trade restrictions; the rise of Deng Xaioping and the reform movement following Mao’s death; the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989; international and trade relations at the expense of human rights recognition; President Clinton’s visit in 1998. Also briefly looks at human rights issues in Burma through an interview with the Burmese Opposition Leader, Aung San Suu Kyi who has been politically isolated under house arrest for over 9 years, followed by a comparison to Taiwan, a mainly Chinese capitalist society, democratic and free and a thorn in China’s side. Includes interviews with Henry Kissinger (US National Security Adviser 1969-75), Paul Wolfowitz (US Assistant Secretary of State, Asia 1982-86), Winston Lord (US Foreign Policy Adviser 1970-73) and Sir Alan Donald (British Ambassador, Beijing 1988-91) among others. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
